Graphical abstract The ammoxidation of ethane over the conventional metal oxide and Co/zeolite catalysts faces the challenge of inadequate selectivity owing to the formation of CO2, N2, and NOx. Here we report that Sn modified ZSM-5 catalyst is highly selective for ethane ammoxidation. The C- and N-based acetonitrile selectivities are up to 80 % and 70 % over the Sn/HZSM-5, but they are below 60 % and 20 %, over the Co/HZSM-5. We suggested that the Sn (IV) cations are the critical active sites for acetonitrile formation, and the presence of nanosized SnOx particles favors CO2 formation. Transient kinetics analysis suggested that ethane ammoxidation over the Sn/HZSM-5 follows the same reaction pathways as that over the Co/HZSM-5. However, the surface abundancy of the reaction intermediates over these two catalysts is different, which could be the reason for the enhanced selectivity over the Sn (IV) cations in contrast to the Co (II) cations in the ZSM-5 zeolite. Keywords Ethane Ammoxidation Sn/HZSM-5 Selectivity Acetonitrile 1 Introduction The transformation of ethane to petrochemical feedstocks, such as ethylene, acetonitrile, and aromatics, could have far-reaching implications on the chemicals synthesis due to the unprecedented increase in natural gas liquids production. However, the direct conversion of ethane remains a formidable challenge due to the inertness of the CH σ bond with sp3 hybrid (the weakest CH bond energy in ethane is 419.5 kJ/mol [1]). Although extensive research has been carried out on the catalyst development for ethane conversion, the existing catalysts are still facing challenges of inadequate activity, selectivity, and/or stability. Among the various catalytic systems, the ammoxidation has been studied for the simultaneous production of acetonitrile and ethylene from ethane, in which acetonitrile is an important solvent, or can be converted into ethylamine, acetic acid, and acetamide, as the precursors to medicine, pesticide, and paints. The ammoxidation has been applied in the industry for acrylonitrile production from propylene over the mixed metal oxide catalyst, known as the SOHIO Process [2]. Direct propane ammoxidation has also been investigated over the similar metal oxide catalyst for acrylonitrile formation [3]; however, the ammoxidation of ethane has been less concerned, and the conventional mixed metal oxide catalysts face the challenge of inadequate acetonitrile selectivity owing to the formation of COx, N2, and NOx via probably the different mechanism [2,4–8]. Not until the later 90 s, the Co exchanged zeolite was developed for ethane ammoxidation, stimulated by the fact that metal exchanged zeolites are prominent in activating small alkanes for selective reduction of NOx [9]. The metalδ+ cations exchanged in zeolites are atomically dispersed on the coordinately unsaturated sites to balance the negative charges of the AlO4 − tetrahedral. These cations, as Lewis acids, are catalytically different from the bulk or supported metal oxide. According to the pioneering work by Li and Armor [10,11], the rate of acetonitrile from ethane ammoxidation over the Co exchanged zeolite (Hβ) was raised by 1−2 orders of magnitude in contrast to the mixed metal oxides (Nb-Sb-Al and Cr-Zr-Mo). It is noteworthy that the catalytic performance was dependent highly upon the types of metalδ+ cations, as well as the framework structure of the zeolites [12]. The Co exchanged silica-alumina (non-zeolite), shows significantly lower selectivity and activity than the Co exchanged ZSM-5, and the CoO/Al2O3 did not show any activity on acetonitrile formation [12]. The Co2+ Lewis acid site (exchanged to the AlO4 −) has been considered as the catalytically active sites for ethane ammoxidation [10–17]. In terms of the mechanism and reaction pathways, ethylamine was considered as the key intermediate according to the IR method [17] and ethylamine co-feeding experiment [10]. It was suggested that ethylene (from the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane) in the gas phase was added to the chemisorbed NH3 (on the Co(OH)+), forming the ethylamine intermediate, which was subsequently dehydrogenated (through dehydration with the OH) to acetonitrile over the same Co(OH)+ Lewis acid site [10]. If the OH group on the Co2+ cation was replaced by a chemisorbed NH3, the ethylamine intermediate might lead to the formation of N2 through the NN pairing [10]. Additionally, excessive oxidation of ethylene and NH3 could also result in the formation of CO2 and NOx, respectively, which was most probably catalyzed by the metal oxide, according to Sokolovskii et al. [18] and our recent study [19]. Although the Co exchanged zeolite catalysts, such as Co-ZSM-5 and Co-β, are currently the most effective (highly active) catalysts for ethane ammoxidation, the selectivity of the reaction needs to be further increased. The carbon-based total selectivity of acetonitrile and ethylene is normally ≤ 80 % (acetonitrile selectivity ≤ 60 %), the unwanted CO2 selectivity is up to 20 % among the catalysts [12,19]. In terms of the nitrogen-based selectivity, only 20–30 % of the converted NH3 was transformed into acetonitrile, whereas up to 70–80 % of NH3 was oxidized to N2 and NOx. The massive production of CO2 and NOx might inhibit the commercial application of the Co/zeolites for the ethane ammoxidation. Here we show that Sn modified ZSM-5 catalyst (Sn/HZSM-5), prepared through simple impregnation, is highly selective to acetonitrile and ethylene in ethane ammoxidation reaction. The catalytic performance of the Sn/HZSM-5, with different Sn loading (1, 2, 5, 10 wt%, respectively), was compared with the benchmark Co/HZSM-5 catalysts. Based on the extensive characterization of the catalyst by means of XRD, TEM, NH3-TPD, Pyridine Infrared (Py-IR), UV–vis-DRS, and XPS et al., we demonstrate that the −OH group coordinated Sn (IV) cations that replacing the AlO4 − tetrahedral incorporated into the framework of the ZSM-5 zeolite are the key catalytically active site for acetonitrile formation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts with different Sn loadings were prepared through wet impregnation. The NH4-ZSM-5 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 30, VWR International) was first converted into proton-type through calcination at 550 °C under air for 6 h. The impregnation was performed at room temperature by adding the SnCl4 aqueous solution to HZSM-5 powder dropwise (the volumetric ratio of solution to zeolite was 2:1). The as-made slurry sample was aged for 24 h, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the sample was calcined under flow of air in a muffle furnace at 560 °C for 4 h. The obtained powder samples were pressed into pellets and sieved to obtain a particle size of 20–45 mesh for characterization and catalytic performance tests. The obtained samples with the Sn nominal loadings of 1, 2, 5, and 10 wt% were labeled as Sn1Z5, Sn2Z5, Sn5Z5, and Sn10Z5, respectively. The Co/HZSM-5 catalysts were also prepared by impregnation, detailed procedures for the Co/HZSM-5 preparation can be found from our previous work [19]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were performed on the Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 gas adsorption analyzer. Prior to the measurement, the sample was degassed under high vacuum at 300 °C for 8 h. The total surface area was calculated from the adsorption in the range of relative pressure from 0.05 to 0.25 by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, whereas the total pore volume was estimated at a nitrogen relative pressure of 0.99. The micropore volume and external surface area were calculated from the isotherms by the t-plot method; the micropore surface area was obtained from the difference between the total surface area and external surface area. Pyridine infrared (Py-IR) spectra were performed on a Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer from Bruker. The sample cell was evacuated to 10−2 Pa at 450 °C for 2 h prior to the measurement. The Brønsted and Lewis acid densities were quantified according to the procedures of Madeira and coworkers [20]. The acid strength distribution was estimated from the quantities of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites determined by Py-IR at different temperatures with the Intensity (y axis) processed by Kubelka–Munk equation [21]. The difference in the amounts of chemisorbed pyridine on Brønsted acids between 150 and 250 °C corresponds to the weak Brønsted acid density; the difference between 250 and 350 °C, and the remaining at 350 °C, correspond to the medium and strong Brønsted acid densities, respectively. Similarly, the quantities of Lewis acid sites and Strong Lewis acid sites can be obtained. Note that the total Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were obtained from the results of 150 °C. The ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis-DRS) were collected on a Cary 5000 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment with a polytetrafluoroethylene integrating sphere. Before each measurement, the hydrated Sn/HZSM-5 samples were transformed to their dehydrated form under 10−1 Pa and 400 °C for 7 h, which were then transferred into a sample cell in a glove box (O2 < 0.1 ppm; H2O < 0.1 ppm). Operated at a scan speed of 10 nm s–1, a step length of 1 nm and a slim width of 5 nm, the UV–vis-DRS were collected in a differential mode referenced to their parent H-ZSM-5 zeolites. Ammonia and n-propylamine temperature-programmed desorption/decomposition (NH3-TPD and nPA-TPDec) were performed in a quartz reactor with a volume of 2 ml (ID, Φ = ½ inches). Prior to NH3 and n-propylamine adsorption, the catalysts (0.1 g for NH3-TPD and 0.06 g for C3H7NH2-TPD) were pretreated in Ar at 650 °C for 20 min. Adsorption of NH3 or n-propylamine was carried out at 120 °C under pure NH3 for 30 min and through a pulsing n-propylamine injection until saturation, respectively. For both experiments, the samples after pre-adsorption were flushed with Ar (at 120 °C for NH3 and 200 °C for n-propylamine) for 2 h to remove the physically adsorbed NH3 and n-propylamine. Finally, the temperature of the sample was increased to 620 °C at a ramp of 10 °C/min under the flow of Ar at 20 ml/min. Desorption of NH3 (m/z = 17) was measured during the NH3-TPD by an online mass spectrometer (Agilent 5973). In nPA-TPDec, the desorption of NH3 (m/z = 17), C3H6 (m/z = 41), benzene (m/z = 78), toluene (m/z = 92), and xylene (m/z = 106) were measured with the same mass spectrometer. More detailed experimental procedures for NH3-TPD and nPA-TPDec has been described in our previous work [22]. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku Ultima III X-ray diffractometer with monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (154.06 pm, 40 kV, and 44 mA) in the range of 2θ from 4 to 50° with a scan speed of 4°min−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and STEM-EDX chemical mapping of the sample were obtained using a JEOL 2100TEM (accelerating voltage 200kV) equipped with Gatan camera. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, Perkin-Elmer Optima 5300DV) was used to determine the weight percentage of silicon, aluminum, and tin elements in catalyst samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI Quantum 2000) characterization was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha system equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source (1486.6 eV, operate at 18 kV). The samples were crushed on a mortar thoroughly to a powdery end-point before loading onto a Cu foil. The core-level spectra were monitored by employing pass energy of 23 eV for the high-resolution scans and 188 eV for the survey scans. The C 1s line at 284.8 eV of adventitious carbon was referenced to compensate for surface-charging effects. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic performance of Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts for ethane aromatization was performed in a home-built flow reactor system equipped with an online Agilent 5973 mass spectrometer. Before catalytic tests, 0.1 g of the catalysts were pretreated in Ar (20 ml/min) at 650 °C (ramp 10 °C/min) for 20 min. Prior to each experiment, bypass feed spectra for reactants (10 % C2H6, 10 % NH3, and 6.4 % O2, balance with Ar to reach a total flow of 80 ml/min) were recorded for mass spectrometer calibration and used as a reference for activity calculation. The reaction was initiated by abrupt switching of the influent gas from Ar to reactants at 550 °C under atmospheric pressure at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 64,000 h−1. All the connection gas lines between the reactor and mass spectrometry were heated to 150 °C to avoid liquid products' condensation. A more detailed method for product quantification with the mass spectrometer and the catalytic performance data for Co/HZSM-5 samples have been shown in our previous papers [19,23]. Specifically, from the intensities of different m/z signal (Im/z) from the mass spectrometry, the intensity of each molecule (Imolecule) was obtained through matrix. The Imolecule was then converted to partial pressure based on the external standard calibration. The molecules’ mole flow rate (mol/s) was then calculated from pressure and volumetric flow rate based on the ideal gas equation of state, P i v t o t = F i R T . The space-time yield of different products was finally calculated from: S T Y i = F i m C a t The conversion of reactants was calcinated as: x = F r e a c t a n t , i n - F r e a c t a n t , o u t F r e a c t a n t , i n × 100 % The selectivity to each product was then determined: S i = A m o u n t o f r e a c t a n t s c o n v e r t e d t o p r o d u c t i T o t a l a m o u n t o f r e a c t a n t s × 100 % = F i , o u t × n ( F r e a c t a n t , i n - F r e a c t a n t , o u t ) × 2 × 100 % 2.4 Transient kinetic analysis The transient experiment was realized through abruptly switching the reactor influent gas from inert (Ar) to the reactant mixture (C2H6/NH3/O2) and vice versa, which provides the dynamic information for both the early-stage transient period and the back-transient reaction fade away. During the back-transient, the reactants disappeared from the gas phase immediately, therefore, the rate of the formation of surface intermediates from the reactants is approaching to zero. Assume first-order kinetics, the mole flow of different products, Fi, during the back-transient can be expressed as: F i = F i , 0 e x p ( - t τ ) in which Fi0 is the mole flow at steady-state, and τ is the time constant of decay. More detailed information about the back-transient has been shown in our previous papers [23]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic results The catalytic performance of the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts for ethane ammoxidation was evaluated at 550 °C, atmospheric pressure, and a space velocity (GHSV) of 64,000 h−1. Whereas for the Co/HZSM-5 catalysts, a lower reaction temperature of 475 °C was applied according to our previous study [19]. It must be noted that the Sn/HZSM-5 is less active than the Co/HZSM-5 catalyst; a higher reaction temperature is required to achieve similar conversions with that over the Co/HZSM-5 (see Fig. S1 for the conversions over the Co/HZSM-5). Table S1 compiles the results of different catalysts in ethane ammoxidation. While the Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst is less active (requires a higher reaction temperature), it shows significant high selective to acetonitrile. More detailed catalytic results of the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts with different Sn loading for ethane ammoxidation are shown in Fig. 1 (panels a, c, and d). The product selectivity (Fig. 1a) over the Sn/HZSM-5 was first compared with that over the Co/HZSM-5 (Fig. 1b). As shown in Fig. 1a, the Sn/HZSM-5 samples exhibit higher acetonitrile selectivities than the Co/HZSM-5 samples. The carbon-based acetonitrile selectivity SACN (C) is up to 80 % over the 2 wt% and 5 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 samples, whereas it is < 60 % (see Fig. 1b) over the Co/HZSM-5 with the same Co loadings. What is more interesting is the nitrogen-based acetonitrile selectivity SACN (N). Over the Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst, the SACN (N) is slightly lower than the SACN (C) at 70 %; however, the SACN (N) is only < 20 % over the Co/HZSM-5 catalysts, which suggested that up to 80 % of the converted NH3 was oxidized to N2 or NOx. The SACN (N) significantly lower than the SACN (C) was also found by Li and Armor in their pioneering study of Co/zeolite for ethane ammoxidation [14]. In terms of ethylene selectivity SC2H4, the 1 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 shows up to 38.8 %. The SC2H4 decreases significantly with increasing Sn loading. The SC2H4 was 10 % over the 2 wt% Sn/HZSM-5, and was decreased to 5% with increasing Sn loading to 5 wt%, and the SC2H4 was almost 0 over the 10 wt% Sn/HZSM-5. However, over the Co/HZSM-5 catalyst, the SC2H4 is in the range between 20–25% when the Co loading is varying between 1−10 wt%. Finally, the CO2 selectivity SCO2 was increased with increasing metal loadings over both Sn and Co modified HZSM-5 catalysts. At low metal loadings, the Sn/HZSM-5 shows lower SCO2 than the Co/HZSM-5. The SCO2 is only ∼6.3 % on the 1 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 sample. Fig. 1c shows the conversion of ethane, NH3, and O2 over the Sn/HZSM-5. Ethane and NH3 show a very similar conversion between 10–15%, and it is surprising that the conversion remains similar (slightly decreased) with increasing Sn loading. The O2 conversion is higher than that for ethane and NH3 due to the lower partial pressure of O2 in the reactants mixture. The O2 conversion shows the same trend as the ethane and NH3 conversions with the increase of Sn loading from 1 to 5 wt%. The O2 conversion further increased with increasing Sn loading to 10 wt% due to the increases in CO2 selectivity. The space-time yields (STY) of C2H4, CH3CN, and CO2 from ethane ammoxidation are shown in Fig. 1d (after time-on-stream of 60 min at the steady-state) and Fig. S2 (versus TOS, no significant deactivation was observed within 200 min). The STY of CO2 increases almost linearly with increasing Sn loading, whereas the STY of CH3CN first increased with increasing Sn loading from 1 to 2 wt%, then decreased linearly with further increasing of the Sn loading to 10 wt%. The maximum CH3CN yield up to 140 μmol/g/min was obtained over the 2 wt% Sn/HZSM-5. In terms of the STY of C2H4, it decreases with increasing Sn loading, during which a sharp decrease from 90 μmol/g/min over the 1 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 to 17 μmol/g/min over the 2 wt% sample. The STY of C2H4 was almost 0 over the 10 wt% Sn/HZSM-5. It must be noted that the blank test of the reactor system produces only a negligible amount of CO2 (∼0.2 %) with the absence of C2H4 and CH3CN. Additionally, pure HZSM-5 also shows negligible catalytic activity towards ethane ammoxidation (see Fig. S3). Therefore, the catalytic behavior observed over the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts mainly originated from the Sn-related species. The Brønsted acid sites of the HZSM-5 alone are inactive for the ethane ammoxidation, although it might show promotion effect to the Sn species with a neighboring position. 3.2 Catalyst characterizations The Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts were then subjected to the extensive characterization of the physicochemical properties. The textural properties determined by the nitrogen physisorption and the chemical compositions according to ICP-AES of the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts and pure HZSM-5 zeolite are shown in Table 1 . The pore size and surface area of the samples slightly decreased after the impregnation of Sn species and suffered a minor loss with the further increase of Sn loading from 1 to 10 wt%. The total BET surface area is in the range between 354.5 and 319.3 m2/g, and the micro surface area is ranges between 244.1 and 211.5 m2/g. The decreased surface area and pore volume/size with increasing Sn loading suggested that the micropore structure of the zeolites was partially blocked by the Sn species. The chemical compositions of the Sn/HZSM-5 samples were discussed based on the Si/Al and Sn/Al molar ratios. As shown in Table 1, Sn/Al ratio was increased from 0.1–5 with the increase of Sn nominal loading from 1 to 10 wt%. The Sn loading of the samples measured by ICP deviates slightly from the nominal loading. The real Sn loading for the Sn1Z5, Sn2Z5, Sn5Z5, and Sn10Z5 are 1.3, 2.1, 5.8, and 9.8 wt%, respectively (see Table 1). The Si/Al ratio of the pure HZSM-5 zeolite is 11.9, which increased to 14 with the presence of 1 wt% Sn and further increased with increasing Sn loading. The Si/Al ratio was increased to 82 when the nominal Sn loading is 10 wt%. The significantly increased Si/Al ratio with the increase of Sn loading suggested that the framework Al was partially removed through dealumination by HCl generated from the SnCl4 precursor during preparation. It is rational that the hydrolysis of SnCl4 solution created an acidic environment during the impregnation process. Additionally, the exchange of Sn (IV) cations with the proton of zeolites also resulted in the formation of HCl. Therefore, part of the Al can be converted to AlCl3 and removed during the later calcination [24]. The vacant T-atom site created due to the dealumination can be replaced by the Sn (IV) cation, which forms either closed [SnO4] or open [Sn(OH)O3] tetrahedral sites, according to Li and coworkers [25]. Further evidence for the incorporation of Sn to the zeolites will be shown later. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the HZSM-5 host and the Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst with different Sn loading. As we can see, the crystallinity of Sn/HZSM-5 samples is close to that for HZSM-5. The XRD patterns for the Sn/HZSM-5 samples maintain a typical HZSM-5 diffraction pattern, indicating that the MFI zeolite structure was intact even significant dealumination was observed with the higher Sn loading samples. The diffraction of Sn related species was absent. For instance, the diffraction peaks at around 29.9 and 34.3° for the (110) and (101) crystal face for SnO2 [26] were not identified, probably due to the low Sn loading and the high dispersion of the Sn species. The unit cell parameters (UCP) a, b, and c (calculated via Jade software (see Table S2)) were slightly increased with increasing Sn loading. Such unit cell volume expansion may suggest that the Sn species were partial incorporation into the zeolite framework [27–29]. Although the Sn species were absent from the XRD patterns, further TEM and STEM-EDS characterization suggested the presence of SnO2 nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 3 a, spherical nanoparticles were clearly identified from the TEM image. The average size of the nanoparticles is ca. 8.9 ± 0.5 nm according to the statistically counting the particles in the different TEM images. According to the HRTEM (see Fig. 3b), the interplanar distance for such nanoparticles is 0.335 nm, which corresponds well to the 110 crystal face for the rutile SnO2 according to the standard card (JCPDS41-1445). According to the STEM-EDS mapping at a lower magnification shown in Fig. 3c, the SnO2 nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed on the surface of the catalyst crystalline, which remains homogeneous even when the Sn loading was doubled (see Fig. S4 for the EDS mapping of 2 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst). While the nanosized SnO2 particles were primarily presented in the fresh Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3d, the population of such particles was significantly decreased after the catalytic reaction due to the redisperation and aggregation. Nevertheless, the Sn content before and after the reaction remains similar (see Fig. S5). Additionally, we suggested that such nanosized SnO2 particles are not desired for the selective ammoxidation, which is further discussed later. The acidities of the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts and pure HZSM-5 zeolite were characterized extensively by NH3-TPD, nPA-TPDec, and Py-IR. As shown in Fig. 4 , the total acid sites quantified from NH3-TPD and the Brønsted (and strong Lewis) acid sites according to nPA-TPDec both decreased ‒ almost linearly with increasing Sn loading from 1 to 10 wt% ‒ with the presence of Sn species. The reason for the decreased total acidity is two-fold. First, the weak Lewis acids from the extra framework Al was removed (see Fig. S6 (a)); second, the acids in the inner micropore night be partially blocked due to the presence of SnOx nanoparticles. The Sn (IV) cations could exchange with the protons of the framework AlO4 − tetrahedral and resulted in the dealumination due to the formation of HCl. Therefore, it is not surprising that an increased Sn loading will result in a decrease of the Lewis and Brønsted acidity. According to the literature [30–35], the incorporated Sn (IV) cations in zeolite are strong Lewis acids, which are prone to bonding with water produced during the reaction and can be interconverted among Sn species with different coordination (tetrahedral and octahedral coordinated) [24,36,37]. It is noteworthy that the synergistic effect of Sn Lewis-Brønsted acid pairs could promote the acidity for Brønsted or Lewis acid sites [38,39]. The acidity of the catalysts was further characterized by the Pyridine Infrared (Py-IR), see Fig. S6 (b) for the Py-IR spectra obtained at 150 °C. As shown in Table 2 , the trend of total Brønsted acidity density from the Py-IR is generally in line with that determined based on the nPA-TPDec. The presence of Sn decreased the total accessible acid sites. Specifically, the majority of the acid sites are strong Brønsted (SB) acids, which account for 56–70 % of the total acid densities. However, the quantity of Brønsted acids and total acid sites according to the Py-IR are significantly lower than those obtained from the NH3-TPD and nPA-TPDec. We suggested that it might be difficult to compare the absolute acid site density by the different probing molecules. In the present catalytic system, according to the literature [31,34,36,40], the acid sites originated from the Sn-related species in the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts might include: a) Sn Lewis-Brønsted acid pairs (-Sn-OH-Si-OH-Al-) remain the most strong acidity [39,41]; b) isolated Sn Lewis acid (-Si-O-Sn-OH, as open Sn); and c) Sn incorporated into the framework (-Si-O-Sn-O-Si-, as close Sn). The accessibility of the different probing molecules to these different acid sites could be varied. Pyridine, due to the steric effect, could not simultaneously probe the Lewis and/or Brønsted acids with high proximity, such as pairs. The Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts were further characterized by the UV–vis-DRS and XPS spectroscopies in order to elucidate the chemical properties of the Sn species. As shown in Fig. 5 a, strong adsorption at a wavelength of 210−300 nm is discernible for all Sn/HZSM-5 with different Sn loadings, which can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 227, 244, and 269 nm, respectively. While the two adsorption peaks at 227 and 244 nm, both can be assigned to Sn (IV) cations in zeolite framework (as Lewis acid sites, supposedly tetrahedral coordinated) [25,27,34], the difference between these two species was not discussed in the literature. We anticipate that such a difference might be originated from the open and closed Sn (IV) cations incorporated into the framework. The broad peak at 269 nm can be ascribed to extra-frame bulk SnOx species [25,27,34]. The semi-quantitative analysis based on the area of the deconvoluted peaks (see Table S3) suggested that the relative percentage of SnOx species are increased from 16.7%–54.5%, and Sn (IV) cations decreased with increasing Sn loading from 1 to 10 wt%. Besides the UV–vis-DRS, the XPS spectra at Sn 3d region (see Fig. 5b) again suggested the formation of Sn (IV) cations incorporated into the framework of HZSM-5 zeolite. According to the literature, the peaks at 487.6 and 496 eV for the 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 spectra, respectively, for the 1 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 can be assigned to the tetrahedrally coordinated framework Sn (IV) cations [25,34]. The peaks shifted to lower binding energy with the increase of Sn loading. For the 5 and 10 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 samples, the 3d 5/2 peak was centered at ∼486.7 eV, which can be deconvoluted into peaks at 487.6 eV for the framework Sn (IV) cations and at 486 eV for the octahedral SnOx species [42,43]. Quite similarly, the 3d 3/2 peak for the samples with high Sn loading can be deconvoluted into peaks at 496 eV for the Sn (IV) cations and 494.4 eV for the SnOx, respectively. Therefore, the XPS results again suggested that the concentration of SnOx increased with the increasing of Sn loading. Additionally, the XPS spectra of the Sn1Z5 and Sn2Z5 catalysts after ethane ammoxidation (at 550 °C for 3 h), and their corresponding fresh samples (after activation) are shown in Fig. S8. The spectra for the used samples are almost identical to that for the fresh samples, indicating the valence state of the Sn species is not changed during the ethane ammoxidation, although the structure has been changed. 3.3 Discussions The catalytic results shown above demonstrated that Sn modified HZSM-5 catalyst is highly selective in ethane ammoxidation to acetonitrile, although the activity is lower than the conventional Co/HZSM-5. Specifically, both C- and N-based selectivities of CH3CN are up 70–80 % over the 2 and 5 wt% Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts. Whereas the C-based selectivity is <60 % and N-based selectivity is only 20 % over the Co/HZSM-5 catalysts. The high selectivity achieved over the Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst must be associated with the formation of Sn (IV) cations, supposedly incorporated into the framework of the zeolite based on the characterization. The incorporation of Sn (IV) cations into the framework of the ZSM-5 was most probably realized during the impregnation of SnCl4. As already mentioned, the hydrolysis of SnCl4 and the ion-exchange of Sn4+·Cl4 −1 with the H+ of the zeolite could result in the formation of HCl during wet-impregnation. Therefore, part of the AlO4 ‒ tetrahedral can be extracted from the zeolite framework (see Si/Al ratio in Table 1), creating the vacant T-atom sites as suggested by Li et al. [25]. Consequently, the Sn (IV) cation will be inserted into the vacant site forming either closed [SnO4] or open [Sn(OH)O3] tetrahedral sites. While both UV–vis-DRS and XPS spectra suggested the formation of Sn (IV) cations, the relative fraction for such sites decreased with the increase of Sn loading. The UV–vis-DRS and XPS spectroscopies, as well as the electron microscopy, also suggested the formation of SnOx particles, which, however, increase with increasing Sn loading. According to our recent study on the Co/ZSM-5 catalyst for ethane ammoxidation [19], as well as literature work on the metal oxides catalysts [1,18], the SnOx particles are expected to be responsible for the CO2 formation from ethylene oxidation in the present case. According to Baerns et al. [44], metal oxide particles that have more than two lattice oxygen species are favoring the formation of COx during the propane oxidative dehydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 6 , the space-time yield (STY) of CO2 increases almost linearly with increasing SnOx concentration in the Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts. The intercept (obtained when the SnOx concentration is 0) might be the intrinsic activity of CO2 formation on the Sn (IV) cations. The tetrahedral coordinated Sn (IV) ions are expected to be the key catalytically active sites for ethane ammoxidation. However, the specific role of various Sn (IV) species in the ammoxidation remains unclear. Although the UV–vis adsorption peaks at 227 and 244 nm are assigned to Sn (IV) cations with either −OH coordinated open cations or close SnO4 tetrahedral, there is no direct relationship between the yield of acetonitrile and the concentration of the Sn (IV) cations according to the UV–vis-DRS. The STY of CH3CN or total STY of CH3CN and C2H4 decreases slightly with increasing Sn loading (Sn (IV) cations) because the ethane ammoxidation involves the sequential reaction steps with C2H4 as the main intermediate. The C2H4 produced from the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane was followed by two parallel steps, namely, the ammoxidation (to CH3CN) and total oxidation (to CO2) [12]. Since the STY of CO2 increased with increasing Sn loading, then it is not surprising that the STY of CH3CN decreased. Additionally, with the Sn loading increase, the total acid density and Brønsted acid density both decreased (see Fig. 4). According to our recent study on the Co/HZSM-5 catalyst for ethane ammoxidation, the Brønsted acid sites have a positive effect on CH3CN formation [19]. According to Wichterlová et al. [45], the activity of ammoxidation is higher than the dehydrogenation on CoH-zeolites, which contains excessive Brønsted acid sites, whereas the activities of both reactions are identical on CoNa-zeolite (with no residual Brønsted acid sites). Therefore, the decreased Brønsted acid density (with increasing Sn loading) could also result in a decrease of CH3CN yield. Further discussion was made based on the step-change transient kinetic experiment. As shown in Fig. 7 a, apparent time delays for different products to reach steady-state were observed during the early-stage transient. While the C2H4, CO2, C2H6, and O2 appear immediately after switching the reactor flux from Ar to C2H6/NH3/O2, both NH3 and CH3CN are absent during the first 3 s. We noticed that C2H4 runs into the maximum immediately (1−2 s) after the switching, which is followed by rapid decreasing to 60 % of the maximum in the next 1−2 s when all the rest molecules reach the maximum. The formation of CO2 follows the same tendency as the C2H4, but the profile shift towards the upright of the Figure. The production of CO2 reaches the maximum at 3 s, and then also experienced a decrease from 5 to 9 s. The unique features of C2H4 and CO2 profiles suggested that ethane oxidative dehydrogenation is occurring prior to the build-up of the NH3-related surface intermediate species. The early-stage profiles of NH3 and CH3CN are almost identical; they are both completely absent from the gas phase during the first 3 s and then increased to the maximum during the next second for CH3CN (it seems like NH3 takes few more seconds than CH3CN to reach the maximum). The strong chemisorption of NH3 on the acid sites of the catalyst could significantly change the catalyst surface coverage, which consequently leads to CH3CN formation. Such early-stage behavior over the Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst is very similar to that over the Co/HZSM-5 [19]. Therefore, the reaction pathways for the formation of the different products over the Sn/HZSM-5 could be the same as that over the Co/HZSM-5 catalyst proposed by Li and Armor [10]. The back-transient (switching back from reactants mixture, C2H6/NH3/O2 = 4/2/1, to Ar) decay analysis are shown in Fig. 7(b–d). The normalized molar flow rates of reactants and products are shown in panels b and c, respectively. It is seen that the scavenge of reactants (C2H6, NH3, and O2) are completely different from the products (C2H4, CH3CN, and CO2). For the reactants, ethane and O2 disappeared from the gas phase immediately, similar to the behavior of inert during the blank test. It takes a longer time for the complete desorption of NH3 from the Brønsted acids of the catalyst. In terms of the products, they attenuate exponentially after the initial maximum (see Fig. 7c). The exponential decay of the products suggested the pseudo-first-order kinetics for the product desorption from the surface intermediates [23,46]. Additionally, the C2H4 profile was found to be bimodal. The presence of the second largest peak strongly suggested that C2H4 could be the most abundant substance intermediate (masi). With respect to the time constant τ, a longer space-time was found for C2H4 (τ = 39 s) than CH3CN and CO2 (17 and 19 s, respectively). We also noticed that the time constant τ for C2H4 (τ = 39 s) is actually similar to that for NH3 (τ = 42 s), which suggested that the surface of the catalyst was highly covered by NH3 (on the Brønsted acid sites) and C2H4 (on the Sn (IV) metal sites) during the steady-state reaction process. It must be noted that the back transient kinetics of ethane ammoxidation over the Sn/HZSM-5 is totally different from that over the Co/HZSM-5. CO2 and NH3 have been determined as the masi, and C2H4 disappeared from the gas phase immediately like the ethane and O2 over the Co/HZSM-5 catalyst [19]. Therefore, the enhanced selectivity over the Sn (IV) cations in contrast to the Co (II) cations in the ZSM-5 zeolite must be associated with the surface abundancy of the reaction intermediates with affinity to Sn active sites. Based on the transient results, we suggest that during the early stage, part of the −OH groups on the open Sn (IV) sites were removed/replaced by the NHx through dehydration. In the meantime, ethane was activated (through oxidative dehydrogenation [9–16]), and ethylene (or C2H5 +) then was dominating the Sn (IV) sites with either OH ligand [9–16] or NHx. The ethylene type intermediate was followed by CN linkage on the same Sn (IV) sites through further H removal as H2O with the assists of O2. On the other hand, more larger amounts of NH3 were chemisorbed on the Brønsted acids as NH4 +, which could serve as NH3 reservior [19], hence promoting the CN linkage on the nearby Sn (IV) sites. The more precise mechanism and the elementary reaction steps require further study based on the combined approach of experimental and theoretical. 4 Conclusion We show that Sn/HZSM-5 catalysts prepared through simple impregnation demonstrated remarkable selectivity in ethane ammoxidation. The C-based acetonitrile selectivity up to 80 % and N-based selectivity up to 75 % were obtained over the 2 wt% Sn/HZSM-5. With the increase of Sn loading from 2 to 10 wt%, both C- and N-based selectivity decreased, and CO2 selectivity increased. According to the UV–vis and XPS spectra, the higher CO2 selectivity at high Sn loading could be related to the formation of excessive SnOx nanoparticles. The ICP results show significant dealumination (by HCl from SnCl4 hydrolysis and ion-exchange), which create vacant T-sites for the Sn (IV) cations and finally form either closed [SnO4] or open [Sn(OH)O3] tetrahedral sites as suggested by the UV–vis and XPS spectra. While the Sn (IV) cations have been considered as the key catalytically active sites for acetonitrile formation, the presence of excessive Sn species could decrease the Brønsted acid density and result in a decrease in the yield of acetonitrile. According to NH3-TPD and nPA-TPDec, the total acid density and Brønsted acid density both decreased almost linearly with the increase of Sn loading. Consequently, the direct relationship between the yield of acetonitrile and the concentration of Sn (IV) cations can not be identified. Further transient kinetics analysis based on the step-change of the reactor influence suggested that ethane ammoxidation over the Sn/HZSM-5 follows the same reaction pathways as that over the Co/HZSM-5. However, the surface abundancy of the reaction intermediates over these two catalysts is different. Ethylene is most likely the masi during the reaction and could be the reason for the enhanced selectivity to acetonitrile over the Sn (IV) cations in the ZSM-5. coredata.dc:description: The ammoxidation of ethane over the conventional metal oxide and Co/zeolite catalysts faces the challenge of inadequate selectivity owing to the formation of CO2, N2, and NOx. Here we report that Sn modified ZSM-5 catalyst is highly selective for ethane ammoxidation. The C- and N-based acetonitrile selectivities are up to 80 % and 70 % over the Sn/HZSM-5, but they are below 60 % and 20 %, over the Co/HZSM-5. We suggested that the Sn (IV) cations are the critical active sites for acetonitrile formation, and the presence of nanosized SnOx particles favors CO2 formation. Transient kinetics analysis suggested that ethane ammoxidation over the Sn/HZSM-5 follows the same reaction pathways as that over the Co/HZSM-5. However, the surface abundancy of the reaction intermediates over these two catalysts is different, which could be the reason for the enhanced selectivity over the Sn (IV) cations in contrast to the Co (II) cations in the ZSM-5 zeolite.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective Sn/HZSM-5 catalyst for ethane ammoxidation to acetonitrile and ethylene
